premise: The object is gently placed on the conveyor directly above wheel M. Initially, the object has zero velocity relative to the ground, while the belt is moving at 6 m/s.
conclusion: There will be a frictional force that accelerates the object until it reaches the same speed as the belt.

premise: Object mass: m = 3 kg, Gravitational acceleration: g = 10 m/s²
conclusion: The normal force is: FN = mg = 3 × 10 = 30 N

premise: Coefficient of kinetic friction: μ = 0.3, Normal force: FN = 30 N
conclusion: The frictional force is: Ff = μFN = 0.3 × 30 = 9 N

premise: The friction acts in the direction of the belt's motion, since the belt is trying to 'drag' the object forward.
conclusion: This friction will accelerate the object until it reaches the belt's speed of 6 m/s.

premise: Frictional force: Ff = 9 N, Displacement: L1 = 10 m
conclusion: The work done by friction is given by: W = Ff × d = 9 × 10 = 90 J

premise: The friction force is doing positive work on the object, transferring energy from the conveyor belt to the object to accelerate it from rest to the belt's speed, and then to maintain that speed against any other forces.
conclusion: The work done by the frictional force of the conveyor belt on the object as it is transported from point M to point N is 90 Joules.
